review_title: Great Place for the Care of Native Americans
pros:
Contribute to care for the Native people
The ability to use Native themes and approaches
Qualified and passionate providers
cons:
Difficult parking
Strained neighborhood due to homelessness needs

review_title: Good organization trying to make a positive community impact
pros: Immersion in native American culture and values, good mission and organization is doing positive work in the community. Lots of opportunity. Extremely diverse.
cons: Pay is lacking, even among non profits. Can be somewhat disorganized and hard to find information.

job_title: Registered Medical Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: You get to interact with all patients and learn from doctors you’re with. It’s great if you want an intro into the medical field
cons: Turn overs are very quick. You also burn out very fast. Especially during the height of the pandemic

pros: Being of service Nice coworkers
cons: Deception and lack of transparency in Leadership Not supportive of mission when it comes to staff support and care Abusive management styles are rewarded Breaking down moral of staff Using staff's love of serving the community against them when staff advocate for their own needs.

job_title: Health Policy Analyst in Seattle, WA
pros: Experience advocating at the national level
cons: If you enjoy lateral oppression and violence this is the place for you. Be ready for non confrontation mixed with a lack of communication. The policy director has limited managerial experience so she doesn't know how to lead staff let alone lead a project.

review_title: Do not work here if you care about your well-being.
job_title: Public Health Worker in Seattle, WA
pros: Co-workers, health benefits, and 401K.
cons: A toxic work culture where you are treated like "family". Lateral violence is an issue, if you bring up concerns to your manager, instead of dealing with the concerns and working with you to come up with good sustainable solutions, they tell their superior and are forced to sit through an 8-hour workshop about it. You are micromanaged to the point where you can't do your job without it going through 5 steps of reviews and it still has to be reviewed by upper management. Too many pointless meetings. Each department is siloed and even if you have the same degree and do work that works directly with the community, you are paid less. Being bullied or belittled by people on your team.

review_title: Great place to start, amazing benefits. Not a lot of opportunity for growth
pros: Amazing team. Passionate people to work with
cons: If you are not in leadership, you are easily dispensable, and it can be felt through communications with management, your work, etc. For an expensive place like Seattle, the pay wasn't great.

pros: Thenworknn no is important for indigenous communities.
cons: Physically unsafe area of the city; low pay and consistent exploitation of employees; extreme disconnect between leadership and lower level staff; emotional manipulation; leadership consistently taking credit for the hard work of the staff they “supervise”; inappropriate shouting from the CEO and Directors when hosting meetings about salaries; nepotism.

pros: The patients are great, and most of the healthcare staff try their best to be supportive and resilient in spite of the intensely toxic workplace.
cons:
Probably THE MOST TOXIC WORKPLACE I've personally experienced. Upper management is generally incompetent and corrupt across the board. There is very little transparency at any level of the organization. Bullying tactics and gaslighting are utilized often in response to questions, comments, or criticism from front-line staff. Once, they made the entire healthcare team come in for a mandatory Saturday meeting to berate about ~70 of us for not being grateful enough for all of the "work" they do, and "how dare" that someone had filed a whistleblower complaint against them. The overall day-to-day actions of the current leadership do not align with the things they say, the plans they make, or the values they say they hold. Employee retention is not great, and there are roughly 50 jobs currently posted at this organization, for good reason. 

Please do your due diligence, ask your friends, colleagues, and acquaintances for word-of-mouth reviews before applying or accepting a position here. Make sure you are well aware of what you are getting yourself into and that the organization will be a good fit for you. Your mental health and well-being are worth so much more than the stress and trauma this place will cause you...

review_title: Good cause, good work, good benefits, harmful effects, harmful culture, harmful pay
pros: Amazing work and colleagues there (past and present)
cons: Terribly (unqualified?) management and toxic bullying

review_title: Toxic work environment , extremely poor management, nepotism, harassment
pros: The relatives (patients) there , All of the providers are amazing
cons: Very poor dis organized management , nepotism , harassment , micro management . You hardly never get a break and management expects you to have many meetings over lunch (with pay of course , they also require a huddle 5 minutes before start of day and 5 minutes before your lunch is over . I was harassed and dealt with a coworker who constantly stalked me and touched my arm on a few occasions and management did not take my issue seriously they tried to schedule a mediation and told me I had to get along with him . I also was being harassed by a patient and the CEO told me “ he probably has generational trauma “ .

review_title: Rewarding work, idealized vision, bad work culture
pros: The work is rewarding and I am proud of what I do knowing it benefits the community. The Urban Indian Health institute's Director is really wonderful and works hard to make an inclusive, fun working environment.
cons: The work culture everywhere else is not the greatest and encourages burnout. People are afraid to take time off. I am afraid to add more info about myself in case of retaliation. There is a lot of nepotism.

pros:
The Urban Indian Health Institute - the Director of this program, has fostered an inclusive work environment.

The same goes for the medical residency program.
cons:
Not client-centric. There is entitlement amongst some of the long-term staff that has caused poor work performance that significantly impacts client care. 

The CEO fosters a toxic work environment, and there’s a lot of backbiting. The executive management has a lot of big ideas but little ability to execute them. I watched many talented executive and management team members leave the organization because of the poor leadership.

pros:
- The organization does a fantastic job of centering Indigenous people
- Great community and the organization cares about the employees
- Amazing benefits
- Lots of opportunities to learn new skills and work on different projects
- A true 9-5
cons:
- Leadership can be unorganized and a bit nepotistic
- Pay is not competitive, even for other non-profits

job_title: Community Relation Advocate in Seattle, WA
pros: Hard working co workers. Co workers are very supportive of each other
cons:
Poor management, to many NEW 
 management positions. High turn over

pros: The employees are great, benefits good and holidays are many
cons:
Executive team is clicky and not trust worthy
They thrive on working employees to exhaustion and paying the lowest they can get away with

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Seattle, WA
pros: Open caring organization providing healthcare services
cons: Becoming corporate culture focused more or growth than employees

pros: They take in drug addict and alcoholics for treatment
cons: The staff, residential assistants, RA's, treat the clients like as if they are in jail.  I joined this center, think it was going to be an enlightened Native American facility, helping people deal with addiction, What I found was a center full of non-Natives running the center like a prison. They would scream and yell at the residents/clients, with no regard for respecting another human being.  The staff openly talked about the client's medical issues and laughed about them. The leads treated their staff badly, and I could see why there was such a high turnover in employees at Thunderbird. Sad to say, there was nothing Native American about this treatment center.  They did not make their clients feel apart of the tribe.

pros: Great mission, great clinic, great clinical staff guided by mission
cons: Weird policies from HR to accounting. Very micromanaging.  A 25+ year employee died suddenly while I was working there and staff were told to get supervisor approval and that they must take vacation time to attend.  I wish I was kidding but I am not; the day I decided to leave.  Also not flexible about flex time even if you do not have a clinical or admin job - one size fits all policies make employees feel less than valued.

pros: The pros have diminished after FEHB health insurance was canceled in favor of Group Health.
cons:
The current mission of the SIHB is to promote upper management and create a “culture” that points to an organization with much more money, influence and importance than the SIHB actually possesses. The main aims of management seem to be to increase the salaries of management, create new and unnecessary jobs at high compensation levels and to keep doctors by paying them higher than average salaries. (Doctors also get a large portion of their college debts paid by working at SIHB.)

Improving healthcare and outcomes for all SIHB patients, seniors, veterans, teens, those suffering from domestic violence? Increasing use of the clinic by the Native American community? These things are NOT on management’s or the Board of Directors’ radar or to-do list.
 
There is great inequality at SIHB between the “important people” and everyone else. Waste and misuse of federal government funds is the norm at SIHB. There is a Pulitzer Prize awaiting a reporter who really digs into SIHB’s past and present and reports the truth. 

As far as Thunderbird Treatment Center? It is understaffed with unqualified employees and presents real dangers for patients; its main buildings are in terrible condition. 

If you are considering a job at the SIHB keep these things in mind:

1.	What is said in your interview is a sales pitch that you should rigorously question and challenge, especially if you’re interviewed by upper management (the CEO). You will be told you will be “empowered.” You will not be empowered; you will be controlled and “guided.” Upper management acts like the SIHB is its “family-owned” business, and the Board of Directors remains silent and gives a stamp of approval to anything.

2.	You will have almost zero power in your job to make decisions or change things for the better, no matter your title; HR is powerless -- A BAD SIGN in an organization. All decisions are made by a very few people. Upper management is especially unqualified in the recruitment area; the more important the job, the more likely a bad hire will be made. Creating unneeded upper management positions at SIHB is the norm. 

3.	You will be working at a place where the majority of workers are unhappy, scared of losing their jobs, and “act out” this unhappiness by fighting with each other. Employees are constantly arguing and complaining and quitting.

4.	For the most part, you will be surrounded (even in upper management) by people who do as little work as they can get away with and who are hired for positions they are not qualified to fill. Since SIHB staff can’t do their own jobs, they get assistants and/or consultants to “help” them (at a high monetary cost to the SIHB). 

5.	Unless you are a doctor or in upper management, you will be paid poorly compared to like jobs in Seattle.

6.	The SIHB is shrinking (not growing) after at least 15 years of careless, unethical and greedy mismanagement by past and present “leadership.” Favoritism and nepotism are the norm: if you are liked (and never challenge management) you get a new title and more money; people are hired for jobs because of family connections, not ability. 

7.	The Board of Directors is distant and disconnected from SIHB operations; they don’t know what funds are available or how those funds are being utilized. On Board of Directors meeting evenings, I heard board members state openly “I don’t have time for this.”

I am very sad to say that if you are a patient in need or a job seeker, for your own physical and mental well-being go elsewhere for your medical care and your career.

review_title: I used to love working here
pros: Passion for improving the health of urban natives, an innovative health center with a ton of potential for those of us who grew up on the rez and want to find connection in the city.
cons: Bad management, little respect for long time employees. I worked here for 6 years, but when my supervisor changed everything went downhill and leadership did not address the issue.

pros: Great Mission, Dedicated Staff, staff reflects the patient population, centrally located and close to restaurants for lunch.
cons: Low pay. Power in the organization is top down. High turnover and lack of industry experience among upper managers. Zero growth. Budget supported by Medicaid expansion lends the company to financial risk.

pros: nice people in medical and dental clinic
cons: terrible management; vindictive, negative, no support to staff
